content.description: Steep hard climbing up crimps and pockets. The crux is between the first and second bolt involving a undercling two finger pocket and a small crimp pocket. After pulling the crux the climbing stays consistent. You really can't relax until after you have clipped the chains. really fun powerful route.
content.location: Five feet to the right of There.

content.description:
A must do!

A great route that heads up the left arete of an aesthetic leaning block. Nice edges and arete lead to a tough crux up high. It is amazing the level of pump this route cam deliver in 35 feet. The crux is in the last 8 feet and has lead to many heartbreaking falls on the last move.

A bit of a clipping crux on the last bolt before the chains.
content.location: Located on the lower tier. At the junction head down the hill across fallen trees then slightly up hill at the edge of the clearing arriving at a streaked leaning block(about 100 yard from the junction). The line is the left most line on the slightly overhanging side.

content.description: Start out on 15 feet of 5.11 climbing to some jugs by the second bolt make sure you chalk up because you won't get the chance again for a while. From the second bolt do a v4/5 boulder problem to the fourth bolt. Deal with a tricky clip and then straight into the crux a v6/7 boulder problem to a jug and the fifth bolt. Relax and deal with 15 feet of 12a to the top.
content.location: The other black streak 10 feet left of Mano-y-mono.

content.description: Great movement through small pockets. Sustained climbing all the way to the top, the best route on the wall.

Sustained crimps and monos to a crux between the fourth and fifth bolts then the route ends with twenty feet of fun five eleven climbing. This route could be classic but there are a lot of manufactured holds. Kind of a disappointment but it's still one of the most beautiful climbs i've seen.
content.location: On the streaked wall just left of Kiss my Quaking Aspen.

content.description:
The route heads up an arete and pocketed face. The route is fingery with most face holds being 2 finger pockets. Strong fingers subtle footwork and a couple long reaches will get you to the top of this stellar route.

I would give it 4 stars if it were not for the first move which is a bit awkward and unpleasant due to a small section of choss that should be your feet.

Once established on the wall 6 feet up, the route is the best arete I have ever had the pleasure of climbing.

(A note for those concerned about ethics, One hold does appear to be manufactured. The route is so good I suggest not getting your panties in a bunch and climb it anyway.)
content.location: Located on the upper tier. If you continue up the hill at the junction the first wall you come upon will be an amazing streaked wall. Route ascends the right arete on the wall.

content.description: A really cool seam feature that lays back using good flakes and smears for feet. Decent warm-up.
content.protection: 2 bolts to chain. Safer than it sounds just bring a sick clip for the first bolt.
content.location: Located on the upper tier. Once you arrive at the streaked wall you will see a chossy overhang to the right of the wall. the route is on the backside of this feature. Walk under the overhang up hill 20 feet and you will see the obvious seam.

content.description:
This route dances from right of the first bolt to left of the second, just right of the third over the forth then left of the anchors for the finish. It's a lot of movement over a short vertical distance. Small fingers and pointy toes help with the send.

It took considerable cleaning to remove some rotten veneer on the bottom and midway up. Always be mindful of additional rock peeling on a new route. It's prudent, especially for the belayer, to wear a helmet.
content.location: Head to the Upper Tier of Principality. It is located to the far right of the crag on a triangular detached boulder just in front of the taller wall behind it.

content.description:
A technical, just under vertical route up an eye-catching black streak.  Expect small pockets and features, lots of footwork, and a wandering line that keeps you thinking and searching for ways to progress upwards.

Step off a large boulder and tweak past the initial crux using small pockets to a horizontal break.  An easier but confusing section weaves past a shallow scoop, and some spaced edges to welcome finger bucket and a long section of easier but balancy climbing to another horizontal break below a small roof.  Pull over roof(beware of the large loose flake!!!) and jaunt up edges and pockets to rap bolts.

Overall a great route.  Personally, this felt like 5.11 so be ready for more of a challenge than the proposed grade suggests.
content.protection: Bolts to rap anchors.  No chains.
content.location: In middle of Lower Tier area.  Look for a rock formation with pretty black streak.

content.description: Slabmaster route. Ascend reachy and hard to find pockets and edges up long steep slab.  Requires delicate foot work on small edges and pockets. The crux is in the last 10 feet, it offers very little in the form of actual holds requiring precision footwork.
content.protection:
7 bolts to Rap anchors.

Seemed a little run out in sections up higher on the route but the falls are safe.
content.location:
Located on the lower tier. From the leaning block you can see the routes directly up and right, its the clean blank face.

A trail used to lead directly up to the route but a massive tree has fallen over the path. Find a way around the tree to the base of the route.

content.description: Slightly over hung face to right of Kiss My Quaking Aspen
content.protection: Gear in horizontal crack 2/3 of the way up the route

content.description: Obvious wide crack to right of Pricipality Head Wall.
